description: Collapse-phase mapping of HPD patterns across domains and narrative scales. HPD traits often manifest as instability in interpersonal relationships, self-image, affect, and marked impulsivity. The following structure outlines recurring collapse patterns in symbolic form across multiple nested systems.

narrative_cues: I need constant attention or I feel empty.
If no one is watching, I don’t exist.
Watch me shine—everyone should see this.
If I’m not the center of attention, what’s the point?
Why won’t they look at me anymore?
Maybe I should become someone else to stay interesting.
No one cares. Maybe I was never special.
If I can’t be adored, I’ll disappear.
My child should adore me completely.
If I’m not the fun parent, I’m nothing.
I’ll be the perfect parent in front of others.
Let’s take selfies for everyone to see.
My family’s love feels conditional, I need more.
Why aren’t they clapping like they used to?
I feel invisible in my own home.
Maybe I’ll just leave and see if they miss me.
Our image is our power.
We must always be seen as cutting edge.
All eyes on the visionary leader.
We’re nothing without buzz and applause.
Let’s rebrand again—it’s time for something fresh.
People are losing interest. We must go bigger.
We’re being mocked now.
All that glitter was empty flash.
Everyone wants to be seen.
Visibility equals value.
Drama drives clicks.
Let’s manufacture conflict for ratings.
Audiences are bored, viewership is dropping.
Reinvent the narrative—fast.
The algorithm has moved on.
We’ve become yesterday’s headline.
